headline.main: A War Game (Sort of), but You Can't Control the Action

lead_paragraph: As a teenager John Klima spent his allowance at the video arcade, plunking quarters into Donkey Kong in a relentless quest to defeat the evil ape. Now Mr. Klima, a New York artist, is playing a different sort of game, using the visual language of computer amusements to depict the not at all amusing war in Afghanistan. Although Mr. Klima's online artwork, ''The Great Game,'' is based on news events, it is among the first Internet projects to address Sept. 11 and its global impact in an aesthetically creative manner rather than in a strictly documentary one. And as digital artists finally start to produce works inspired by the terrorist attacks and their political aftermath, the documentary efforts may be becoming more provocative, too: an M.I.T. professor has a plan, which may or may not be realized, to send a robot into Afghanistan to do the on-ground reporting he says the Pentagon is not allowing the press to do.
abstract: Article on The Great Game, 3-D Internet project by John Klima that is updated daily on World Wide Web (www.cityarts.com/greatgame) to show latest military manuevers in Afghanistan; Klima comments; photo (M)
